Introduction

Postmenopausal bleeding (PMB) is defined as any vaginal bleeding occurring more than 12 months after the cessation of menses.  Approximately 5%-10% of women experience PMB, which can range from a single bleeding episode to daily vaginal bleeding.  PMB can occur due to a variety of conditions, many of which are benign, but it is also a common presentation of endometrial cancer.  Therefore, all patients presenting with PMB require a thorough evaluation.

Etiologies



Although PMB is mostly of uterine origin, it can also occur due to bleeding from other locations in the urogenital tract (eg, vulva, urethra, cervix).  The source of bleeding can be divided into nonuterine etiologies, uterine structural etiologies, and uterine nonstructural etiologies (with an emphasis on endometrial hyperplasia and cancer).

Nonuterine etiologies



  • Genitourinary syndrome of menopause (vulvovaginal atrophy):  the thinning and inflammation of the vulvar and vaginal epithelium due to decreased estrogen can lead to bleeding, particularly with tissue trauma (eg, due to sexual intercourse or pessary placement).
  • Pelvic organ prolapse (
    figure 1
    ):  herniation of the bladder, bowel, and/or uterus through the vagina can cause protrusion of the vaginal wall beyond the vaginal orifice, causing tissue exposure and tissue friability, ulceration, and bleeding.
  • Sexual assault and intimate partner violence:  may present with PMB, with evidence of genital tract lacerations and bruising.

Uterine structural etiologies



  • Endometrial polyp (
    figure 2
    ):  benign growths of the endometrium that can cause bleeding by disrupting the surface integrity of the endometrial lining; a common cause of PMB
  • Cervical cancer (
    figure 3
    ):  can cause PMB due to cervical friability, particularly with advanced disease

Uterine nonstructural etiologies



  • Endometrial atrophy:  a common cause of PMB.  After menopause, decreased estrogen levels cause thinning of the endometrial lining, leading to increased friction and inflammation from the denuded endometrium.
  • Coagulopathies:  commonly occur secondary to medications (eg, antiplatelets, anticoagulants), but they can also occur secondary to certain medical conditions (eg, thrombocytopenia, von Willebrand disease).

Endometrial hyperplasia and cancer



  • Endometrial hyperplasia/cancer:  the most concerning cause of PMB.  Both endometrial hyperplasia and cancer occur due to prolonged, unopposed estrogen exposure to the uterine lining, leading to its excessive proliferation and malignant transformation.  This should be suspected in patients with risk factors, including obesity, hormone replacement therapy (particularly if progestin is not used), tamoxifen use, or family history (eg, Lynch syndrome).

Diagnosis, evaluation, and management



Evaluation (

figure 4
) of PMB aims to, first, rule out endometrial hyperplasia/cancer; second, rule out cervical cancer; and, third, diagnose the potential etiology.

History and physical examination



Nonuterine etiologies and iatrogenic causes secondary to medication are often readily identified based on patient history and physical examination (eg, visible excoriations or vulvovaginal tissue thinning).  Depending on the amount of bleeding, a complete blood count may be indicated to evaluate for anemia.  In addition, patients taking anticoagulant medications may require coagulation studies.  Regardless of the results of the examination and laboratory evaluation, all patients with PMB require full evaluation of the cervix and endometrium.

Cervical evaluation



Patients should undergo evaluation for possible cervical cancer with a Pap test and human papillomavirus cotesting.  In addition, any obvious lesions on pelvic examination should be biopsied for histopathology.



Patients with cervical dysplasia or cancer on Pap testing and colposcopy should be treated based on cervical cancer guidelines, discussed in detail in the cervical cancer article.

Endometrial evaluation



Regardless of the results of Pap testing and colposcopy, the endometrium should be evaluated.  Initial evaluation of the endometrium can be performed through transvaginal ultrasonography or endometrial sampling.



Although transvaginal ultrasonography cannot provide a definitive diagnosis, it is a reasonable first step for patients with a lower suspicion for malignancy (eg, normal BMI, no use of hormone replacement therapy) because it is less invasive and less painful than an endometrial biopsy.  Transvaginal ultrasonography is used to evaluate for endometrial thickness and can help identify endometrial polyps, fibroids, or other structural abnormalities:



  • Endometrial thickness of â‰¤4 mm generally indicates a low risk for malignancy, and the patient can be observed and monitored with serial transvaginal ultrasonographies.
  • In contrast, endometrial thickness of >4 mm indicates an increased risk for endometrial hyperplasia and cancer, and the patient requires endometrial sampling.


Endometrial biopsy is the gold standard to rule out endometrial hyperplasia or cancer:



  • Patients with an adequate sample and benign biopsy results can be observed or treated for the other etiology (eg, vaginal estrogen for genitourinary syndrome of menopause).
  • Patients with an inadequate sample or an endometrial polyp require further evaluation with uterine curettage, typically via hysteroscopy with dilation and curettage.
  • Patients with endometrial hyperplasia or cancer require treatment.  A detailed discussion of treatment can be found in the endometrial hyperplasia and cancer article.

Summary



Postmenopausal bleeding is most commonly caused by benign pathologies.  However, it can be a symptom of malignancy, particularly endometrial cancer, and all patients with postmenopausal bleeding require a full evaluation.
